newsitem.title: USA: World Semiconductor revs fell 10 pct in 1996 -- IDC.
newsitem.headline: World Semiconductor revs fell 10 pct in 1996 -- IDC.

text.p: The semiconductor industry's revenues worldwide fell 10 percent during 1996, the first annual decrease in more than a decade, according to International Data Corporation (IDC).
The market research firm said semiconductor revenues were $129.2 billion in 1996, a 10 percent drop from 1995.
But IDC forecast a rebound for the chip market in 1997, with revenues expected to total just below 1995 levels.
Although demand for chip products remained strong in 1996, an inventory glut and resulting price erosion caused revenues to decline, the research firm said.
As expected, the Metal Oxide Semiconductor (MOS) memory chip market was hit the hardest. Revenues fell 36 percent, according to IDC estimates.
The MOS Logic segment did experience some slight gains in 1996 and the micrologic segment was the industry's one bright spot with a 15 percent revenue increase.
Computer microprocessors make up the largest portion of the micrologic market and reached revenues of $17.1 billion. The market is largely dominated by Intel Corp.

It said it expected worldwide memory revenues decline another five percent to $32.4 billion in 1997, with two types of memory chips, Dynamic and Static Random Access Memories dragging the segment down. The actual number and complexity of devices is expected to rise dramatically

The personal computer market will continue as the major customer for memory chips, but markets such as consumer electronics and communications are expected to provide increasing opportunities for memory chip growth, it said.
